long_desc.thetext: path problems on windows; need to write windows specific unit tests

I can confirm that everything works fine when TransformerFactory pproperty is passed to the JVM; this is more to do with JDK//JRE settings on windows than with UTF-X; this factory should be specified somewhere in a p[roperties file

issue.short_desc: Test fails if source/expected doesn't start with an element

long_desc.thetext:
This happens for the following (both source and expected): * empty * text only blah blah * first node is text SurnameIYYYY,Title
 Results in a NullPointerException being thrown.
this seems to be a bug with the DOM3 serializer. use DOMWriter to serialize these kind of nodes as a workaround.

issue.short_desc: Suite level source-builder is not used by tests

long_desc.thetext: A source-builder has been specified at the start of the test definition. If a test then specifies use-source-parser="yes" a NullPointerException is thrown and no tests run. A source-builder needs to be specified in the test for use-source-parser="yes" to work.
the problem was trying to set the SourceBuilder on a TestSuite which had not been created yet

issue.short_desc: Validation of XSL:FO for expected doesn't work

long_desc.thetext:
Validation fails with message similar to the following:
[[line 2, col 234]: Attribute "xmlns:fo" must be declared for element type "fo:block".]
The fo namespace has been declared on <utfx:tests> element, and the <utfx:expected-validation> specifies the fo.dtd.

RenderX XSL:FO DTD does not declare xmlns:fo attribute on fo:block element; if namespace declaration is placed on fo:block then validation will fail; if you don't put the fo namespace declaration (explicitly or implicitly via the framework) then validation will fail as well as the namespace is not declared (catch 22)
the only solution/workaround I can think of at the moment is to declare xmlns:fo attribute on fo:block, fo:inline etc elements.
please use the FO DTD shipped with 0.0.5 alpha; see address book sample.

issue.short_desc: use-source-parser is ignored

long_desc.thetext: if there is a <utfx:source-builder> element at the top level, it is always invoked even if use-source-parser="no" is specified on the <utfx:source> element.
the source was always passed through sourceBuilder.getSource. now just use a StreamSource if use-source-parser is "no"

issue.short_desc: some named template tests do not work

long_desc.thetext: this happens if the named template assumes that the current context node is what it expects. currently all named templates are called from the root node (i.e. utfx-wrapper), which is not always correct, instead the current context should be set to the first child element of <utfx-wrapper>.
named template tests are now run in the context of the first element in utfx:source

issue.short_desc: building the source fails in certain cases

long_desc.thetext: this can happens when validate="no" and use-source-parser="yes". the root element is not initialised, so an invalid DOCTYPE is generated. also rawSource is not set under this situation, so an empty fragment is passed to the SourceBuilder.
fixed the logic with the different combinations of validate and use-source-parser attributes

issue.short_desc: default attributes are automatically added to <expected>

long_desc.thetext: if a DTD is used for validating <expected> fragments (may also apply to <source>) then the parser will automatically populate the fragment with default attribute values if they were not specified. This changes the content of the <expected> fragment and causes tests to fail where they would otherwise pass.

this is only an issue when a test definition file references the <expected> DTD.
For example, when an XML editor is used to author UTF-X test definition file for an XHTML generating XSLT stylesheet then the following can be added to the DOCTYPE to enable the XML editor to understand XHTML:
<!ENTITY % xhtml1_dtd PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "xhtml1-transitional.dtd"> %xhtml1_dtd;
this most likely will cause problems when running the test.

this is not really a defect, just the way XML works. User should be able to tell their parser not expand entities by setting a parser feature. This should be looked at again in the future, but stopping a parser from expanding entities by hardcoding it in the framework is not the right solution

issue.short_desc: stylesheet out of synch with the DTD

issue.short_desc: utf-x tries to validate source if utfx:source-validation element is not present

long_desc.thetext:
if a test definition file does not have <utfx:source-validation> element but validate="true" attribute is present on a <utfx:source> element then the framework attempts to validate the fragment ... and obviously fails cos no DTD is defined. validate="true" should be ignored on <utfx:source> elements unles <utfx:source-validation> is specified.
Same applies to <utfx:expected> !

XSLTTestCase now ignores validate="true" on <utfx:source> and <utfx:expected> elements if correct validation method was not specified in the test definition file i.e not present on the parent XSLTTestFileSuite
will be released in 0.0.6

issue.short_desc: utf-x does not work on Windows

long_desc.thetext:
looks like file paths (test xml reference to xsl stylesheet) aren't handled properly on Windows platform.
The test xml references the xsl as just "ooo2xhtml.xsl" but it gets translated to c:\SDT\ice\apps\xhtml-export\ooo2xhtml.xsl (correct - the xsl is there) which is then somehow being translated into c:\C:\SDT\ice\apps\SDT\ice\apps\xhtml-export\ooo2xhtml.xsl (which obviously is not there. c:\SDT\ice\apps\ is the location of the build.xml and utfx.properties files)
see error below, also attached utfx log file.
javax.xml.transform.TransformerException: Had IO Exception with stylesheet file: c:\SDT\ice\apps\xhtml-export\ooo2xhtml.xsl at org.apache.xalan.processor.StylesheetHandler.error(StylesheetHandler.java:921) at org.apache.xalan.processor.StylesheetHandler.error(StylesheetHandler.java:964) at org.apache.xalan.processor.ProcessorInclude.parse(ProcessorInclude.java:315) at org.apache.xalan.processor.ProcessorInclude.startElement(ProcessorInclude.java:184) at org.apache.xalan.processor.StylesheetHandler.startElement(StylesheetHandler.java:638) at org.apache.xml.utils.TreeWalker.startNode(TreeWalker.java:390) at org.apache.xml.utils.TreeWalker.traverse(TreeWalker.java:202) at org.apache.xalan.processor.TransformerFactoryImpl.processFromNode(TransformerFactoryImpl.java:148) at org.apache.xalan.processor.TransformerFactoryImpl.processFromNode(TransformerFactoryImpl.java:247) at org.apache.xalan.processor.TransformerFactoryImpl.newTemplates(TransformerFactoryImpl.java:775) at org.apache.xalan.processor.TransformerFactoryImpl.newTransformer(TransformerFactoryImpl.java:702) at utfx.framework.TestFileSuiteAssembler.assemble(TestFileSuiteAssembler.java:160) at utfx.framework.XSLTTestFileSuite.suite(XSLTTestFileSuite.java:126) at utfx.framework.XSLTTestDirectorySuite.suite(XSLTTestDirectorySuite.java:94) at utfx.framework.XSLTRegressionTest.suite(XSLTRegressionTest.java:55) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:585) at junit.runner.BaseTestRunner.getTest(BaseTestRunner.java:111) at utfx.runner.TestRunner.start(TestRunner.java:196) at utfx.runner.TestRunner.main(TestRunner.java:217) Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: c:\C:\SDT\ice\apps\SDT\ice\apps\xhtml-export\ooo2xhtml.xsl (The filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect)

issue.short_desc: need to improve/automate distribution packaging

long_desc.thetext: apparantly the zip file unzips files read-only. I think this happens on Windows XP; will confirm with the person who reported the bug.

as discussed, a package target is needed. This target should construct a distributable package by constructing zip file of appropriate structure from appropriate project files. This process should NOT simply zip up project directory. Further on structure to follow....

Need to create a distribution or package target in the build file. This target should create three seperate distributable ZIP files:
1. Full source + all libraries 2. Binary + all libraries 3. Binary + libraries but excluding XML parser/XSLT processor (default d/l)
Both binary distribution should include all jar files, rendered samples and documentation. Binary distributions should not include source or any files used only in the UTF-X development process.

issue.short_desc: report validation errors in xsl and test xml

long_desc.thetext: If the xsl or xml is invalid, you just get a message saying "0 tests" and you have to view the log file to see any errors. It would be useful to see any validation errors in the test summary.

well ... this isn't an easy one. the problem is that tests are being built by the JUnit framework and there are no hooks into that process. If a test build fails we can only log the error message (this may already happen). If a single test is broken inside a TDF then a MalformedTestException is thrown and displayed during a test run, but this does not deal with not well formed TDF's or broken XSLT stylesheets. We can do one of the following:
1. log errors when either XSLT or XML TDF is broken 2. Have a special BrokenTestCase which fails/errors when executed 3. Drop JUnit and provide our own core framework. I have actually already implemented this when doing some experiments. 4. Check out JUnit 4.0 to see if it provides any callbacks for the test assembly process.
I have raised this issue with Erich Gamma at the 2004 JavaOne and he told me he was aware of the problem; perhaps he fixed this in junit 4,.0
other thoughts anyone?
Created an attachment (id=7) prooposed output format

please have a look at the attached screen shot. tests 19 is the result of a not well formed TDF and test 20 is the result of a bad stylesheet. Do we need seperate way of showing bad TDFs and bad stylesheets? I guess the answer is yes.
I'm implementing options 1 and 2

issue.short_desc: AnsiColourResultPrinter does not reset suite name

long_desc.thetext:
if there are TDFs at the same level as test directories with TDFs then the printer will print incorrect test suite name. This is because suite names are only set upon entering a suite and assumption was made that every suite name will be set correctly upon starting that suite. this does not work if a TDF follows a suite at the same level (ie a test case is a sibling of a test suite). Test suite names will have to be stored on a stack.
This may also apply to other result printers.

issue.short_desc: add support for W3C Schema validation

long_desc.thetext: Currently UTF-X only supports validation of source and expected fragments using DTDs. One should be aable to validate either source or expected fragment using an XML Schema.

issue.short_desc: need a way of identifying TDF types for rendering

long_desc.thetext:
currently there is no clear and explicit mechanism for the framework to know how to render TDFs. Obviously it does not make sense to render HTML version out of a TDF which tests a stylesheet that generates XSL:FO. So we'll need to do one of the following:
A) provide an explicit mechanism for describing the generated output format (eg via additional element in a TDF). B) implicitly work out the intended output format by examining the TDF and XSLT

proposed solution:
add tdf-render element with output attribute; output attribute can be either html or fo
or is this going to limit people from rendering into other formats eg rtf or svg???
There is already an optional output attribute on utfx:stylesheet (xhtml | fo) - or is this something different?

Correct Sal; forgot about this; question remains: do we want to limit output formats by this attribute? Do you guys use this attribute? If you do use it then I'll just use it as the output format identifiier, hence issue resolved
will use exisitng attribute as per Sally's comment
yes we use this attribute

issue.short_desc: t.g. should be able to use sample XML for generating TDF

long_desc.thetext: currently the test generator parsers the stylesheet and generates tests based on the templates found in the stylesheet. for each template test generator creates an element with some text, passes the element through the stylesheet and uses source and output to form a utf-x test. It would be helpful if a user could also pass a sample XML document (or W3C Schema) to the generator (as well as the XSLT) and use that document/schema as the source of element structure. Generated tests would be then much more meaningful

first working version. namespaces still don't work and additional logic should be added. for example the root element dumps the whole document in utfx:source and the rendition in utfx:expected which is bad. This will do for 0.0.8

issue.short_desc: The addres book sample is incomplete

long_desc.thetext: Need to complete both XSLT stylesheets and the corresponding tests. Also need a larger sample XML document. You may want to add other elements to the DTD. I don't really care what you do with as it is a stand alone samples and does not have to comply with any utf-x structure/style rules. In fact it would be better if it was different to other stylesheets and TDF in the framework to show a slightly different way of using UTF-X.
its very simple but it works and all tests pass on saxon8/linux; will test other combinations b4 release 0.0.8

issue.short_desc: stylesheet out of synch with the DTD

long_desc.thetext: XSL:FO stylesheet does not work as it is out of synch with the DTD
as far as I can see all bits are now rendering correctly. leaving the issue open for now as I will do some further cleanup over the next two days
completed

issue.short_desc: utfx-wrapper can produce invalid results

long_desc.thetext:
we currently use <utfx-wrapper> to wrap utfx:source content before processing through the transformer. Problem with this is that a template that matches '*' will also match <utfx-wrapper> and therefore produce crap. I have encountered this in the utfxdoc samples where I have match "*" template to process any non utfxdoc elements and display the content using syntax highlighting.
We'll need to remove the <utf-x wrapper> element!
I've used mode="xml" on my match="*" template which makes this work but this is not a fix just a work around. The main thing is that utfxdoc sample tests now work correctly
we are now using the xmlverbatim stylesheets; this issue no longer applies

issue.short_desc: need a XSLT 2.0 stylesheet test

long_desc.thetext: currently all tests (and samples) use XSLT 1.0 stylesheets; we should ensure the framework works with XSLT 2.0 as well.
got one test which workks with saxon8 and correctly breaks with non xslt 2.0 compliant xalan

issue.short_desc: Move from DTD to XSD

long_desc.thetext: I want to move away from using DTD and switch to XML Schemas for all DTDs used in UTF-X. DTD validation support will remain at least for a while. The new utfx test definition file namespace is http://utf-x.sourceforge.net/xsd/tdf_1_0/tdf.xsd and it points to the schema

implemented tdf.xsd and changes all tests and samples accordingly also changed the namespace in UTFXNamespaceContext class
from now UTF-X is no longer backwards compatible with older TDFs

Sice we don't want to change the schema frequently I'll be making all forseen modifications for release 0.0.8. The changes are ralated to multiple issues (not listed here) and are will be as follows:
1. change root element to 'tdf'; TDF is more than just a list of tests 2. change the constructor-params types to use xsd types rather than the list of Java types. This will make the TDF language independant and will allow for future ports to other languages such as C# 3. add xml-fragments element which can store XML fragments. These fragments should be referencable from within the tests. This will allow for reuse of XML fragments 4. change source and expected so they can reference the fragments including an option to select a fragment of a fragment using xpath (perhaps need to use element name other than fragment) 5. Add elements to allow for passing of parameters to stylesheets and named templates.

Schema documentation availabe here: http://utf-x.sourceforge.net/xsd/doc/tdf.xsd.html
Please update this documentation (generated with oXygen XML) with every commit

issue.short_desc: source and expected should be able to refrence content via URI

long_desc.thetext:
Need to add a feature whereby <utfx:source> and <utfx:expected> elements can reference content from external file or document embedded elsewhere in TDF. Both options should be able to select a node sequence by using an XPath expression.
original feature request: ------------------------ I've been using the utf-x framework to help in developing some quite complex, or at leas to me their complex, XSL style sheets. I can honestly say I couldn't have done it without the utf-x package.
Some of my test xml can get quite long, that is the XML I want to transform, and the expected result. I was wondering if there is a way to have include statements. Something like this would be brilliant.
<utfx:test> <utfx:name>Test Name</utfx:name> <utfx:assert-equal> <utfx:source validate="no" src="full_record_input.xml"> </utfx:source> <utfx:expected validate="no" src="full_record_output.xml> </utfx:expected> </utfx:assert-equal> </utfx:test>
Does such a thing exist? Or is it ouside the scop of utf-x?
working on changes to the schema

issue.short_desc: utf-x does not work with Saxon 8 on Windows

long_desc.thetext: Xalan fails to correctly import import the stylesheet from the wrapper when running under Windows. Possibly '/' vs '\' issue.
ooops. I meant Saxon 8.

comment after some innititial investigation... : The exception occurs when trying to create a transformer in TestFileSuiteAssembler. Saxon 8 seems to have a problem with the URI in the href attribute of the xsl:import element set in the wrapper stylesheet. This URI does not explicitly set path separators '/' or '\' and is created using java.io.File.getParentFile().... which one would think should be language neutral. Saxon 8 on Windows is the only XSLT Processor/OS combination where this exception occurs so one would susspect some inconsistency between Saxon 8 and Xalan with regards to dealing with xsl:import ... or a just a nasty bug in Saxon 8. Saxon 8 is a XSLT 2.0 processor where Xalan uses XLST 1.0 and there may be difference in the specs regarding the handling of xsl:import. Check XSLT 1.0 and 2.0 specs.
The approach would be to add some code in TestFiileSuideAssembler that serialises the DOM Document containing the wrapper stylesheet to see what exactly is passed to the Transformer. Serialised stylesheet should be checked against both of the specs.
google search on XTSE0165 may prove useful

issue.short_desc: Absolute XPath Expressions can't be used

long_desc.thetext:
The root element passed to stylesheet under test is <utfx-wrapper> and not the child of the <utfx:source> element in the TDF. Therefore absolute XPath expressions can't be used in the stylesheet under test.
============================== STEPS TO REPRODUCE:
Stylesheet under test: <xsl:stylesheet xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" version="1.0"> <xsl:template name="absolute-copy-of"> <xsl:copy-of select="/"/> </xsl:template> </xsl:stylesheet>
TDF: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="../../../src/xsl/test_definition_xhtml.xsl"?> <utfx:tests xmlns:utfx="http://utfx.org/test-definition"> <utfx:stylesheet src="absolute_xpath_tests.xsl"/>
<utfx:test> <utfx:name>absolute xpath test</utfx:name> <utfx:call-template name="absolute-copy-of"/> <utfx:assert-equal> <utfx:source> <root> <branch> <leaf></leaf> </branch> </root> </utfx:source> <utfx:expected> <root> <branch> <leaf></leaf> </branch> </root> </utfx:expected> </utfx:assert-equal> </utfx:test> </utfx:tests>
Actual result: [java] [1] absolute xpath test [java] actual: [java] <utfx-wrapper>< [ DIFF ] utfx-wrapper><root><branch><leaf></leaf></branch></root></utfx-wrapper></utfx-wrapper> [java] expected: [java] <utfx-wrapper>< [ DIFF ] root><branch><leaf></leaf></branch></root></utfx-wrapper>
Expected result: Passed
will try to fix for the next release; note that the test definition file structure will change for the next release

issue.short_desc: implement change history management

long_desc.thetext: need to manage history of changes in an XML file; the history.xml file should show releases with changelog of most significant enhancemts/bug fixes etc. This history should be integrated with issue tracking and CVS logs. It should be a UTF-X sample just as UTF-X Doc.
see files in samples/history

Mikael,
This is probably the only issue left which I want completed before the release of 0.0.8. If you don't have time to work on please let me know so I can assign it to someone else.
-j

Sridhanya,
This is a simple XML app for project history. We need to document what has been changed in each particular release. So the idea is to go through the issues and enter them in apppropriate release; you'll need to do this by the dates. As of now each developer will make their own entry, but we first need to enter information for the past 7 releases. As you can see the information included is the issuezilla extract + CVS log files so in the future we may want to automate a lot of this, but we still want to put information in the <history:comment> element manually so it is in context to the release. You may choose to do more work on the stylesheet but the highest priority for 0.0.8 is to get the data in there and of course write the tests for the templates. Let me know if you have any questions.
-j
in fact do the tests last; 0.0.8 may have to ship with only one complete sample, that is the address_book; the tests are working which is the main thing; utf-x doc tests are out of sync as well

Mikeal,
Great to see you you are back.
by integrated I mean there shuld be somelinking between the two - see the state of current implementation, issue number in change extracts the summary from issues.xml. this will do for 0.0.8, but if you have some great ideas please do let me know

Need more specific input on what needs to be done.
//mikael

just do your best at filling in the details. this will involve looking at what issues were completed for what release; the actual functionality is OK, you don't need to change it if you don't have time, just the actual content of history.xml; if you can add utf-x tests to the history sample then itx a bonus

Hi,
I have updated the history.xml for 0.0.8 and 0.0.7. I cannot find valid information for previous releases. Have I missed that information?
I have some thoughts about the <history:comment>. I suggest that you input the following:
Update/Feature/Change/Bugfix depending on what change that have been made to the code base. Any other suggestions?
Cheers,
//mikael

Mikael,
I like your idea. I'll add 'type' attribute on the change element in the schema.
regarding the earlier releases you can work which issue was completed for which release by looking at the date when each issue was resolved. So for example any issue that was resolved between 26 March 2005 and 21 August 2005 are part of 0.0.6. I know this is little bit of manual work.
-j

Mikael,
I've added the 'type' attribute with 4 possible values: bug-fix, feature, enhancement and general. The first three can be mapped to issuezilla issue type and the last for things that don't fit in -j

Mikael,
date under the release element is the date of the release. The date under change is the completion date of that change for that release. Note: a change (issue) maybe reopened and closed again in future relase, i.e. the change date you need to enter may not be the last completion date of the issue, but in most case it will be. Does that make sense?
-j
the dates should be in iso format: http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~mgk25/iso-time.html
updated issues.xml extract, Mikael you may want to subscribe to the commits mailing list to get notification of code commiits

Should we not use the issues.xml to extract a date? I suggest we use date for last activity for an issue. E.g. looking at issue 33 that would be the folloiwng part.
<activity> <user>jacekrad</user> <when>2006-04-01 12:48:30</when> <field_name>resolution</field_name> <field_desc>Resolution</field_desc> <oldvalue></oldvalue> <newvalue>FIXED</newvalue> </activity>
This is the last activity on this issue. We can use xsl to extract the info for each issue and it would be a lot easier to keep up-to-date. Is it good enough ( I mean there is always exceptions to the rule)?
//mikael

When I look at the history.xml I find the same information in issues.xml. But we don't extract it from issues.xml. We manually add information to history.xml that could be retrived ( xsl) from issues.xml (if we use issuezilla correct). Any specific reason for this? I have added templates in history_xhtml.xsl to retrive the issue_type and issue_date. The point that I trying to make is, that it is very time consuming to manually enter information into history.xml ( especially when it already exists in issues.xml). The only thing , AFAIK, is:
<history:name>0.0.8 alpha</history:name> <history:date>not yet relased</history:date> <history:tag>release_0_0_8_alpha</history:tag>
since it is not in issues.xml
Please give me your thoughts and ideas in this matter.
//mikael

yes, you can use the date, but only if the activity is resolved and resolution FIXED, VERIFIED or CLOSED. We don't want REOPENED for example. To automate this may be difficult because an issue may CLOSED in one release and then REOPENED and FIXED in another

an issue may be reopened if it was found that it wasn't resolved correctly. you are correct, that new issue is created if another problem is found.
Mikael, due large raffic reg this issue lets move the conversation to the dev mailing list. subject issue 44

issue.short_desc: stylesheet needs fixing

long_desc.thetext: very ugly output
major rework. all TDF elements should now be rendered correctly.

issue.short_desc: expected frgment validation fails parsing document

long_desc.thetext: invalid utf-8 character (one byte encoding). This can be reproduced on Windows with the current version (1.6.2.1) of address_book_xhtml.xml TDF. My guess is that the non braking character 0x160 is causing the problem. Oxygen claims that the document is well formed so my guess that this is caused by some intermediate DOM serialisation into a platform specific encoding (which I don't believe is utf-8 on windows). It works for me on Linux where the default platform encoding is utf-8.

further thoughts: the transform test case passes OK and it is the expected validation test cases that fails when parsing. This would indicate that my original diagnosis is correct. It is not the TDF that is broken but the code that runs the validation test case. I think windows default encoding is latin1 which ain't utf-8. I'm just surprised that this problem has manifested it self only now.
just had a look at the code: my guess is that that last line of serialiseNode (Node) in XSLTTransformTestCase should be changed from baos.toString() to baos.toString("UTF8")
now explicitly use utf-8 encoding when converting from String to byte[] and vice versa

issue.short_desc: 5 failures when running rt on windows xp

long_desc.thetext:
in fact there are only 4 failures. This is due to OS specific line ending. either these tests never worked on Windows (I find it hard to believe) or the implementation of java.io.PrintWriter has changed. In either case the CanonicalForm class doesn't correctly handle (translate) line endings on windows XP SP2 F:\workspace\utf-x-0-0-x>java -version java version "1.5.0_06" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_06-b05) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_06-b05, mixed mode, sharing)
this is a serious issue and must be resolved before 0.0.8 is released
oops, imeant p2

I built the dist/${dist.name}_src_full.zip file with the release target on Windows and copied it to Linux, unzipped it and ran the regression tests. Now the same 4 failures happen on Linux. When I build the $ {dist.name}_src_full.zip on Mac OS X and copy it over to Linux everything is fine.
I.e. one has to be careful on which platform to build the release.
fixed 3 of the 4 failures
also fixed the last one
Alex, just had a look at the the changes and at the first glance it seems that the original implementation was correct. The issue is with CVS.
*** Issue 55 has been marked as a duplicate of this issue. ***

fixed CanonicalForm implementation by changing all println() statements to print('\n') which is inline with the W3C Canonical XML 1.0 recommendation.
All tests pass on Linux and Windows. Distribution built on Windows and copied to Linux passes rt; distribution built on Linux and copied to Windows passes rt as well.

issue.short_desc: error parsing utf-16.xml when running rt

long_desc.thetext: on windows xp jdk 1.5.0_06 OK on Linux

in my posting to dev I said that this file dom_writer_test_2_utf16.xml doesn't look very healthy when opened in oxygen on windows, but it looks just fine on linux. I'm wondering if this has something to do with the byte order mark (or lack of it)
anyone interested in solving this issue?
Linux claims this file is little endian but does not tell me if BOM is present

Where can I find the file utf-16.xm?
//mikael
the file name is actually src/java/utfx/util/test/dom_wrtiter_test_2_utf16.xml

At what point is the dom_wrtiter_test_2_utf16.xml executed? What is the purpose of the class?
cheers,
//mikael
ps. Did you have time to specify 'to do's' for issue 44.
its part of the unit test for DOMWriter which is executed as part of the regression test; 'rt' ant target

I built the dist/${dist.name}_src_full.zip file with the release target on Windows and copied it to Linux, unzipped it and ran the regression tests. Now the same error happens on Linux. When I build the $ {dist.name}_src_full.zip on Mac OS X and copy it over to Linux everything is fine.
I.e. one has to be careful on which platform to build the release.

the way I'm going to deal with this is to explicitly say that 0.0.8 has not been tested with utf-16 encoded documents which would be true even if this test has passed. internally we do everything in utf-8 and we would need a lot more tests than this to claim correct operation with utf-16.

This is caused by CVS not understanding that this is a UTF-16 encoded file and trying to translate line ending when checking out on windows breaking the file. This file will need to be checked in as a binary unles we can get CVS to dig UTF-16 encoding.
changed dom_writer_test_2_utf16.xml to a binary file so CVS does not fuck around with EOL markers; now parsers OK on Windows

issue.short_desc: TestRunner with utfx.test.file does not report errors

long_desc.thetext:
Found in branch_0_0_x
STEPS TO REPRODUCE:
* define ant target in build.xml <target name="test" depends="jar"> <java classname="${testrunner}" fork="yes"> <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=$ {tarnsformer_factory_impl}" /> <jvmarg value="-Dutfx.test.file=tests/test/broken_stylesheet_test.xml" /> <jvmarg value="-enableassertions" /> <arg value="utfx.framework.XSLTRegressionTest" /> <classpath refid="runtime.classpath" /> </java> </target>
* ant test
ACTUAL RESULT: [java] OK (0 tests)
EXPECTED RESULT: [java] Tests run: 1, Errors: 1 [java] Java Result: 1
The fix won't make it into 0.0.8 release this weekend. I will fix it on branch_0_0_x.
can be tested with the new testfile-has-error target

issue.short_desc: Support of named templates in TestGenerator

long_desc.thetext: Currently the TestGenerator does not support named templates. It just inserts a comment into the generated TDF: <!-- ignoring name teplate XXX (not yet supported) -->
Added support for named templates with parameters.

issue.short_desc: should render the output into HTML

long_desc.thetext: As well as chosing a result printer to render test run result, one should be able to tell the framework to render the output into HTML and open the file in browser after test run. This HTML rendition should done be via the XMLResultPrinter, which can be done now, but transformation is an additional manual step.
will be completed for 0.0.8; just cleaning up the stylesheet

implementation completed. this process is controlled via the following properties found in utfx.properties
utfx.html-report.generate=yes utfx.html-report.filename=report.html utfx.html-report.open-in-browser=yes
UTF-X will open the report file in a browser on Windows and on Unix if either firefox or mozilla is the PATH. Don't know about Mac.
Now it also works for Mac OS X using the default browser.

issue.short_desc: XMLResulltPrinter does not output test name in error

long_desc.thetext: When createing test summary for errors, the XMLResultPrinter does not output the name of the test that vaused the error
fixed implementation of printErrors(TestResult) method

issue.short_desc: SourceBuilder that has parameters in constructor fails

long_desc.thetext: When you specify source-builder constructor parameters in a TDF, UTF-X seems to use the default constructor for parsing source even though the correct constructor seems to be invoked in SourceParserFactory.
false alarm; it was my implementation the UTFXDocPreProcessor which created a new UTFXDocPreprocessor in its getSource(InputStream) method

issue.short_desc: add libraries to utfx.jar manifest

long_desc.thetext: the manual gives examples of using UTF-X from a command line but does not talk about CLASSPATH. If utfx.jar has all the required libraries in its manifest then it will be much easier to run it from the command line
added manifest with classpath; now you can run any main() class with just: java -cp build/jar/utfx.jar ClassName

issue.short_desc: regresion test has 4 failures

long_desc.thetext: I have just downloaded UTF-X 0.0.8 at work and got 4 failures when running the regression test. I just had my machine at work upgraded and I installed jdk 1.5.0_08. These tests did not fail when I ran then on Windows XP at home. The interesting thing is that the testUTF16(utfx.util.test.DOMWriterTest) test which was failing on Windows now passes for me.
Created an attachment (id=16) Regression Test Report

I've downloaded 0.0.7 alpha and ran regression test. I get 3 error (address book) and three failures, only two of them are CanonicalForm tests (testTransform1 and testTransform7). As far as I remember Alex, issue 47 had 5 failing tests on CanonicalForm, but now I get only 2 with jdk1.5.0_08 and utf- x 0.0.7. Are the four failures in 0.0.8 the same you fixed in issue 47?
I checked jdk1.5.0_08 release notes and can't really see anything that could have caused this. There is, what seems an unrelated to this, change to the SAX parser, but its hard to know without looking at the source code.

I lied, just tried it at home and the same result: 4 failures. When I was testing the distro I think I just ran ant samples and ant tests but not ant rt. I also just relised that I'm running the latest JDK (1.5.0_08) at home as well; upgraded last week.
So the issue must be to do with the fact that I built 0.0.8 on Linux (as Alex pointed out earlier). Does anyone know if CVS converts end of line characters to match the platform? This is what I think is happening because my code tree on Windows works OK, just the distro built on Linux that's causing problems.
So this seems to me as issue 47 again.

Did some checking up and this is what I found out:
Does anyone know if CVS converts end of line characters to match the platform?
Yes, it does. To prevent this, you have to checkin everything in 'binary' mode (-kb). Every other option (-k...) performs this conversion.
Notes: 1. To be more precise: CVS does not do this conversion; it lets the C run-time do this.
2. If you use CVS on Cygwin, and Cygwin is set to use Unix line endings (which I do not recommend, as it results in other problems), then there will be no conversion. Note, however, that some of the outputs of CVS look ugly in this case, too.

Thank you Mikael. CVS is clearly the guilty party. The XML files we are running our unit tests agains differ between Linux and Windows. We'll need to change the way we test CanonicalForm. CVS is also causing problems in issue 48.

This is clearly a duplicate of issue 47
*** This issue has been marked as a duplicate of 47 ***

activity.newvalue: Created an attachment (id=16) Regression Test Report

issue.short_desc: improve printing of non ASCII and white space characters

long_desc.thetext: Currently the result printers print the Expected and actual fragments as is stripping new line characters (I think). If the character that differs is '\n' vs '\r' then the result printers do not show that. Similar situation may occur with high bit, unicode characters which cannot be printed on the terminal or are white space (eg 0x160;). There needs to be an option (either in utfx.properties or the TDF) where one can choose how to print these characters. One option would need to be to print them 'as is' and another to convert them to charcter entities. Attachment in issue 55 clearly demonstrates this problem.

issue.short_desc: XMLResultPrinter stylesheet incorrectly prints OK when tests fail

long_desc.thetext: The message: OK (XXX tests) should only be printed if ALL tests pass, just as it is the case with AnsiColourResultPrinter. The stylesheet currently prints this messages even though tests have failed. The stylesheet seems to behave correctly if there are errors as well as test failures.
Created an attachment (id=17) HTML report
going to start by creating a TDF

issue.short_desc: need a good overview based on a sample

long_desc.thetext: need to write an overview section which explains the relationship between XSLT and TDFs and their rendered versions. The best way to that (I think) is to use a concrete sample such as the address_book. This will allow a person to read the overview and at the same time browse through the actual XSLT and TDF.

issue.short_desc: need better compliance with Caconical XML 1.0

long_desc.thetext:
The CanonicaForm class claims conformance to the Canonical XML 1.0, a W3C Recommendation, 15 March 2001 (http://www.w3.org/TR/xml-c14n). Well, the fact is that it aint compliant.
Need someone to read the spec and come up with a set of new unit tests, and modify the existing tests, to test for the behaviour described in the Canonical XML 1.0 spec. After that we can start on the implementation changes.
alternative (and perhaps preferable) solution would be to use a third party canonical form implementation.

resolution of issue 47 has slightly improved the compatibility; there are at least three issues remaining:
1. EOL character normalisation MUST be performed before parsing 2. method parameters do match those that are specified by Canonical XML 1.0 3. MUST add/test support for all REQUIRED character encodings
Also, even though the implementation may be OK, the class documentation is confusing regarding parameter entities resolution and attribute value normalisation. This has to be tested and documentation corrected.
Note to the implementer: This is not really related to canonical XML 1.0 but to XML 1.1 the two new supported EOL characters 0x85 and 0x2028 should also be normilised

issue.short_desc: test support for UTF-16

long_desc.thetext: need to add tests to test support for utf-16 encoding

added utf_16_stylesheet_tests.xsl and a corresponding TDF, both encoded using UTF-16. This stylesheet is an exact copy of the core_tests.xsl except for the encoding; same applies to the TDF; all tests in this file pass on both Linux and Windows

issue.short_desc: incorrect usagge message

long_desc.thetext: TestGenerator prints incorrect usage message; pls improve the documentation

issue.short_desc: need an option to normalise white space

long_desc.thetext:
need to be able to normalise white space insode elements, so more complex source and expected fragments can be tested even after auto formatting by an XML editor.
For example, one may want to consider the following two paragraphs as equivalent:
<para>This is an example of some long pragraph with text which will wrap if formatted within an XML editor such as oXygen</para>
<para>This is an example of some long pragraph with text which will wrap if formatted within an XML editor such as oXygen</para>
This feature is over and above the Canonical XML 1.0 specification
I need this in order to write the tests for issue 57. At this stage I'll add an attribute at test level; later one we can add option at TDF level and in utfx.properties

specifications: --------------- white space normalisation should be performed on utfx:source and the result of transforming utfx:expected iff attribute normalise-whitespace="yes" is present on the assert-equal element. If this attribute is present and its value is "yes" then any sequence of white space characters (' ', '\t', '\n', '\r') should be normalised to a single space character ( ).
Also see http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#sec-white-space
done

the term 'normalise whitespace' pay be confusing as the CanonicalForm always has normalised whitespace outside elements. The feature discussed in this issue normalises whitespace inside the elements and should be renamed accordingly.
renamed attribute 'normalise-whitespace' to 'normalise-internal-whitespace'. I'll leave this issue open for now to allow for more thorough testing.
seems to work OK

issue.short_desc: Typos in build.xml

long_desc.thetext:
--- build.xml~ 2006-08-23 11:34:36.000000000 -0400 +++ build.xml 2006-09-02 16:26:14.984075200 -0400 @@ -77,15 +77,15 @@ <!--~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~--> <!-- Java 1.5 bundled Xalan XSLTC processor - <property name="tarnsformer_factory_impl" value="com.sun.org.apache.xalan.internal.xsltc.trax.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> + <property name="transformer_factory_impl" value="com.sun.org.apache.xalan.internal.xsltc.trax.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> Xalan XSLTC processor - <property name="tarnsformer_factory_impl" value="org.apache.xalan.xsltc.trax.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> + <property name="transformer_factory_impl" value="org.apache.xalan.xsltc.trax.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> Xalan Interpretive processor - <property name="tarnsformer_factory_impl" value="org.apache.xalan.processor.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> + <property name="transformer_factory_impl" value="org.apache.xalan.processor.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> Saxon 8B XSLT 2.0 processor - <property name="tarnsformer_factory_impl" value="net.sf.saxon.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> + <property name="transformer_factory_impl" value="net.sf.saxon.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> --> - <property name="tarnsformer_factory_impl" value="net.sf.saxon.TransformerFactoryImpl" /> + <property name="transformer_factory_impl" value="net.sf.saxon.TransformerFactoryImpl" />
@@ -216,7 +216,7 @@ <!--~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~--> <target name="rt" depends="jar"> <java fork="true" classname="${testrunner}"> - <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=${tarnsformer_factory_impl}" />
+ <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=${transformer_factory_impl}" />
<jvmarg value="-enableassertions" /> <jvmarg value="-Xmx512m" /> <classpath refid="runtime.classpath" /> @@ -279,7 +279,7 @@
<java classname="${testrunner}" fork="yes"> - <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=${tarnsformer_factory_impl}" /> + <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=${transformer_factory_impl}" /> <jvmarg value="-Dutfx.test.dir=samples" /> <!-- <jvmarg value="-Dutfx.test.file=samples/utfxdoc/test/utfxdoc_xhtml_test.xml" /> --> <jvmarg value="-enableassertions" /> @@ -356,7 +356,7 @@ <target name="tests" depends="jar">
<java classname="${testrunner}" fork="yes"> - <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=${tarnsformer_factory_impl}" /> + <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=${transformer_factory_impl}" /> <jvmarg value="-Dutfx.test.dir=tests" /> <jvmarg value="-enableassertions" /> <arg value="utfx.framework.XSLTRegressionTest" /> @@ -377,7 +377,7 @@ <target name="testfile-has-error" depends="jar">
<java classname="${testrunner}" fork="yes"> - <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=${tarnsformer_factory_impl}" /> + <jvmarg value="-Djavax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory=${transformer_factory_impl}" /> <jvmarg value="-Dutfx.test.file=tests/test/broken_stylesheet_test.xml" /> <jvmarg value="-enableassertions" /> <arg value="utfx.framework.XSLTRegressionTest" />
thank you for the patch

Hi,
Do you mind sending the patch again as an attachement? The issue tracker wrapped a lot of the lines and I can't apply it as it is.
Cheers
Jacek
applied patch

issue.short_desc: need to restructure regression testing

long_desc.thetext: need to restructure regression testing to allow for easy, seperate testing of different UTF-X components
broken up into three: Java Samples Tests all can be executed via FullRegressionTest

issue.short_desc: restructure 'tests' directory

long_desc.thetext: UTF-X tests in the 'test' directory should be broken up into two categories 1. correct tests (expected to pass) 2. incorrect tests (expected to fail or generate error) correct tests should then be included in the full regression test and executed once for each transformer factory impl supported just as the samples

I liked Jacek's proposal in the dev mailing list to seperate into three categories 1. correct tests (expected to pass) 2. failing tests 3. tests with errors
Additionally to testing the correct tests it would be good to check in the full regression test whether the failing tests fail and whether the tests with errors report an error for each transformer factory impl.
new structure: tests/ tests/good tests/good/xslt_1_0 tests/good/xslt_1_0/test tests/good/xslt_2_0 tests/good/xslt_2_0/test tests/failing tests/failing/test tests/error tests/error/test

issue.short_desc: start documenting UTF-X design decisions

long_desc.thetext: I want this to be an informal, internal to the team but publically available document.

issue.short_desc: strange behaviour when using utfx:with-param

long_desc.thetext:
Alex, I have a named template that works, but can't get the test to work. This is strange because you have a similar test in named_template_param_test.xml which seems to work. The problem is that when running the test I can't get any of the nodes that are children of the parameter node. If I add inside the named template then I do get the whole node sequence. I'm note sure what is going on. stylesheet template: ---------------------
Time: ms
OK ( tests) Test run: , Failures: , Errors:

There were failures.

There were errors.

--- test: generated test skeleton for named template 'test-summary' 1352 58 6 4
false alram; I missundestood where the context node was
